ASTR001 is a general introduction into the subject of astronomy, designed for the non-major. This course covers most topics of astronomy, including celestial bodies, large cosmic structures, the origins and future of the universe, and the possibility of extraterrestrial life. The class requires elementary algebra and geometry, and is not recommended for physical-science majors or Engineering students. It fulfills the College Sector VI: Physical World requirement.

Many students found this course to be interesting and accessible, even for those student whose strengths were not in mathematics.

The majority of students praised Professor Devlin as “the best teacher at Penn,” crediting his enthusiasm and vibrant teaching style for helping people enjoy the class. One student commented, “the man could make watching grass grow interesting.”

Many students take ASTR001 to fulfill their Physical World sector requirement. Comments about difficulty varied widely. A few students thought the course was too easy, and that the mathematics was too “dumbed down.” However, the majority of students considered the class to be too difficult, citing the large number of assignments and the exam difficulty. A significant number of students noted that there was a large disconnect between the material learned in class and the exam material, which were harder than expected.
